repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Rural Development in Marginal
            Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Development in Marginal Areas
            Project for Mexico had the following ratings: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that the non-additionality of Bank-lending
            greatly complicates the introduction of new approaches and
            structures for development. Projects that finance small,
            demand-driven community subprojects through decentralized
            implementation structures must greatly simplify financial
            management processes especially those related to the
            validation of disbursements and expenditures. Innovative
            projects and Adaptable Program Loans (APLs) require early,
            in-depth evaluation before new phases, expansions or major
            implementation changes. A strong management information
            system and an efficient administrative structure are needed,
            as in any project. Mainstreaming and scaling-up of projects
            is extremely desirable from many perspectives. Given the
            space and the flexibility, the states can innovate and
            develop appropriate solutions to address implementation
            issues and create more favorable environments for
            implementation, tailored to their particular environment.
            Direct disbursement of resources to farmers' groups for
            their own administration dramatically decreases the time
            required to initiate local projects. The regional councils
            were useful instruments for improving transparency and
            accountability with respect to development investments. In
            the later transition to Departmental and Municipal
            Development Councils these could have remained a bit longer
            in place to transfer their experience and facilitate the
            change to the new structures.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Rural Development in Marginal
            Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Development in Marginal Areas
            Project seeks to improve the well-being and the income of
            smallholders in about 24 targeted marginal areas, which are
            among the poorest of the country, through sustainable
            increases in productivity and better food security. The
            project consists of four components. First, productive
            investments will finance demand-driven investment
            sub-projects for agricultural production, natural resources
            management, processing activities, and productive
            infrastructure. Second, community development will include
            preparation of community-based natural resources management
            plans and small works associated with them; small projects
            related to community activities; and training and workshops
            to facilitate beneficiary participation in the project.
            Third, technical support covers the provision of extension
            services, technical assistance, training for farmers,
            producers organizations, women's groups, and small
            entrepreneurs. Fourth, institutional strengthening and
            project administration will support project management and
            include expenses associated with institutional strengthening.
